title: 104_s1857
content: The "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996" establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices with duties outlined for the Commission. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996," is tasked with studying laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices and may recommend changes. Key considerations include the amount of money spent on campaigns, disclosure of funds, the impact of current laws on qualified candidates seeking office, and the financing system for campaigns. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996," studies laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices. It considers the financing system for campaigns, disclosure of funds, impact of current laws on candidates, access to media for informing the electorate, and other relevant matters. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996," focuses on studying laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices, including campaign financing, disclosure of funds, impact of laws on candidates, and access to media for informing the electorate. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 9 private sector members appointed by various officials, with a chairperson selected within 7 days. The Commission consists of 9 private sector members appointed by various officials. Within 7 days of all members being appointed, they must select a chairperson by majority vote. If the chairperson is not selected within 30 days, all current members will be discharged. Vacancies in the Commission will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members of the Commission will receive compensation. The Commission consists of 9 private sector members appointed by various officials. Members are entitled to compensation based on the Executive Schedule. A quorum of 6 members is required for decisions, and meetings are called by the chairperson or 6 members. The chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint necessary staff without following standard government hiring procedures. Additionally, fast track procedures are in place for recommendations. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing the study conducted. The report may include recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns, agreed upon by 6 or more members. If 7 or more members agree on recommendations for campaign conduct changes, they can prepare bills for submission. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing the study conducted. Recommendations agreed upon by 6 or more members will be prepared as bills for implementation with expedited consideration by Congress. The Commission will cease to exist 30 days after submitting the report. $750,000 is authorized for carrying out the Act.
